positive.review: If you like sim games, this is one of the best. Not only do you have the fun puzzle of how to build efficiently, beautifully, functionally, that other sim games offer, but you have the additional visceral feedback loop of the prisoners telling you how you're doing. Riots? Breakouts? Gangs? These are the things that tell you a reorganization is in order. Much more interesting and personal than a city builder with it's natural disasters or citizens moving away. A great game, lovingly supported for years, and a fun way to lose several hours in a day.
This is a great game to test your design and planning faculties.

What starts as a simple ‚Äúbuild a prison‚Äù concept quickly spirals into a chaotic, yet deeply rewarding challenge of strategy, problem solving, and, let‚Äôs be honest, mild prisoner torment.

At first, you‚Äôre just laying down some walls and hiring guards, thinking, How hard could this be? But before you know it, you‚Äôre micromanaging inmate schedules, optimizing guard patrols, setting up rehabilitation programs, and designing the perfect prison layout. Only to have it all go up in flames (sometimes literally) when a riot breaks out because you forgot to build enough toilets.

The best part? Every prison you build tells its own story. Maybe you go for the ultra secure, military style lockdown where no one so much as sneezes without permission. Or maybe you build a utopian rehabilitation center, only to realize your ‚Äúopen concept‚Äù design has led to mass escape attempts. The possibilities (and disasters) are endless.

And let‚Äôs talk about the moment you think, Just one more day, only to glance at the clock and realize the sun is coming up. The game has that special kind of addictiveness where failure only makes you want to improve, tweak, and try again.

Just don‚Äôt be surprised when your ‚Äúquick session‚Äù turns into a full blown obsession. Keep in mind their are still a few bugs and glitches present even after the developers final sunset update for the game. Prison Architect - ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚ú©

There are management games, and then there‚Äôs Prison Architect, a simulation that somehow makes bureaucracy feel like therapy and catastrophe feel like art.

This game shouldn‚Äôt be as fun as it is. You‚Äôre literally designing containment systems for virtual inmates, and yet it‚Äôs relaxing, absurd, and brilliant all at once.

I‚Äôll say it right away, this game is fantastic.
And also, holy hell, the pricing is criminal.

‚≠ê Core Design & Vision - 1/1

Prison Architect is still one of the most innovative management sims ever made.
It's dark, it's funny, and unapologetically systemic, it knows exactly what it is and doubles down on it. All decisions have consequences, all designs have purpose, and all teeny tiny mistakes become emergent story.

It's a design that has a life of its own. The game doesn't tell stories ‚Äî it lets you make disasters happen.

Tuning your prison into an blueprint of functionality, or turning it into a chain-reaction murder course for fun, the vision behind it all is never sacrificed.

‚≠ê Gameplay & Mechanics - 1/1

Construction is therapy in its most raw form.
Walls, utilities, guards, cameras, the entire package comes together with clean logic and surreal satisfaction. Watching your prison run (or blow up) has the same "sick grin" feel as watching a Rube Goldberg machine disintegrate.

The management layer is solid, well-tuned, and surprisingly replayable. It's an easy thing to spend hours adjusting routines or scheduling executions you tell yourself are "just for testing.".

And then there‚Äôs Escape Mode, where the game flips itself inside out.
You get to tear down everything you‚Äôve built.
You can break out of your own creations or download other people‚Äôs prisons and absolutely wreck them. I‚Äôve spent more hours than I‚Äôd like to admit setting one on fire and running through the chaos with a lighter and a smirk.

This itself keeps it from being another management sim ‚Äî it infuses the game personality, agency, and pure replay value.

‚≠ê Immersion & Atmosphere - 0.5/1

The art style is intentionally minimalist, two-dimensional, cartoonish, and boring ‚Äî and somehow manages to make the experience spookier. The contrast between the cute graphics and the dark material hits harder than any attempt at realism could.

But it's not emotionally connecting. You don't care about systems, you care about people. It's anarchy sandboxing, not a story of mankind. Awesome fun, but never personal.

‚≠ê Stability & Respect for the Player - 0.5/1

Then there's where things turn nasty.
The base game? Fairly affordable.
The whole experience? A $110 CAD investment.

That's what you can invest to construct an actual prison.

The DLC sprawl is obscene. It's not terrible, but it's utterly excessive. Paradox took this stylish indie gem and made it a content buffet that nickels-and-dimes curiosity.

All that being said, the game still plays decently, it's infinitely moddable, and the devs (at least during the Introversion days) did something worth every hour you put into it. You can easily play around the DLC bloat ‚Äî the base game still stands on its own.

‚≠ê Emotional Impact & Legacy - 1/1

Prison Architect has weathered its time.
It remains one of the smartest, funniest, and most deeply surprisingly thoughtful sims ever made. There is a beauty to be found behind the irony, a quirky pride at having subdued anarchy, a laughing grimace as you realize just how much freedom the game gives you to be god and devil.

It is no longer just a management game.
It's an outlet for creativity for control freaks, pyromaniacs, and wannabe sociologists.

Last Verdict - 4/5 Stars ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚ú©

Overall, in spite of the corporate indulgence and the DLC excess, Prison Architect remains an absolute gem.
It's a little simulation, a little social commentary, a little sandbox of stupidity, and yet, by some goshdarned miracle, it all comes together in my book.

Yes, the price of the "complete edition" is exorbitant, but the game itself is still one of the most enjoyable, replayable, and oddly soothing management games to date.

It's proof that even under incarceration, liberty can be what you make it.

üß± Prison Architect ‚Äì 88 Hours In: A Deep Dive Review

After spending 88 hours with Prison Architect, I can confidently say this game is one of the most surprisingly addictive and rewarding simulation experiences out there. What starts as a simple idea ‚Äî build and manage your own prison ‚Äî quickly turns into a complex, layered challenge that tests your planning, management, and problem-solving skills.

üë∑‚ôÇÔ∏è Building and Management Done Right

The building system is incredibly satisfying. Every block, wall, and wire placement feels meaningful. Designing cell blocks, canteens, and security zones scratches that perfect management itch, and when you finally see your layout run smoothly ‚Äî inmates eating, guards patrolling, and everything in order ‚Äî it‚Äôs genuinely rewarding.

The level of customization is fantastic. You can design anything from a humane rehabilitation center to a brutal high-security fortress. The game truly lets you define your own philosophy as a warden.

üî• Chaos, Control, and Consequence

No matter how perfect your setup looks, Prison Architect loves to test your control. Riots, escapes, power outages ‚Äî there‚Äôs always something threatening to turn your peaceful routine into total chaos. These unpredictable moments keep the game fresh even after dozens of hours, forcing you to stay alert and constantly improve your designs.

üí∞ Depth That Keeps You Hooked

Even after 80+ hours, the game still offers new layers of complexity ‚Äî from staff management and reform programs to logistics, finance, and prisoner grading. You‚Äôre not just building rooms; you‚Äôre creating an ecosystem where every system interacts. Watching it all function like a living organism is what makes Prison Architect so addictive.

üé® Presentation and Style

The simple, almost cartoonish art style works perfectly. It‚Äôs clean, readable, and gives the game a unique charm that balances out its darker themes. The sound design ‚Äî the hum of daily prison life, the alarms of riots ‚Äî adds to the immersion without being overwhelming.

‚öñÔ∏è Final Verdict

After 88 hours, Prison Architect still feels endlessly replayable. It‚Äôs one of those rare management games that‚Äôs easy to learn but hard to master, rewarding both creativity and precision. Whether you enjoy designing efficient systems or watching controlled chaos unfold, this game delivers.

I want to enjoy it, I really do. I put in the hours and grind my teeth against the frustrations; but the truth is that it is just too buggy to enjoy. 

The systems just grind to a halt, especially when you have a number of prisoners. Things like laundry just fall to pieces: janitors would rather clean rooms than drop off clean clothes, and it all ends up in a single laundry room anyhow no matter the assignment. There's a well known bug where staff will pick up their lunch and get stuck, thought to be because they are all computing the same seat location: this STILL hasn't been fixed after years. Kitchens will fail to prioritize which canteens to send food to, ending up some being full and others empty, leading to many prisoners starving for little reason.

You focus on fixing your min-sec "freedom" need by editing the schedule for them, usually over a long period of time because that's the only way to determine the real outcome in this game. Then all of a sudden the med-secs are complaining about freedom when you've made NO CHANGES to their part of the schedule, or any physical part of their entirely separate section of the prison for that matter. There's no interaction or causation there leading to it. Makes no sense!

Certain prisoners continue to one hit your guards with the extremely deadly trait, no matter how many contingencies you have in place. Staff morale will always plumet, the only way is to continue to offer pay rises, but after a while doesn't it start to get a bit ridiculous and counterintuitive? By the way, playing with staff needs with weather and having to deal with staff upset about constant warmth is the most egregious thing ever: they are going to be outside at SOME point. Radiators only do so much as it lowers so fast and hard, having morale drop from that with little counter is annoying unless you just concede and build entirely inside.

Once staff morale drops, and it's inevitable over time, it'll continue to drop. With the fights kicking off with little to no reasoning in terms of "needs", sometimes with no solution to be had, and staff continuing to fall likes flies; the procedures you employed still just not working with no explanation.

That's the problem, constantly making amends and forsaking plans just to work around issues and bugs that really shouldn't be there. The fact the game is "finished" in their eyes is disheartening. There are a small number of user mod patches but it's still holding on by the seams. If you stick to under 200 prisoners it seems to work, for the most part, but beyond that it falls to pieces.

The game has so much charm, it's a shame.

Since Paradox took over the game, it has gotten worse and worse. Bugs that haven't been fixed. Annoying Paradox launcher, no option to start the game directly. Lots of paid content.

I want to enjoy it, I really do. I put in the hours and grind my teeth against the frustrations; but the truth is that it is just too buggy to enjoy. 

The systems just grind to a halt, especially when you have a number of prisoners. Things like laundry just fall to pieces: janitors would rather clean rooms than drop off clean clothes, and it all ends up in a single laundry room anyhow no matter the assignment. There's a well known bug where staff will pick up their lunch and get stuck, thought to be because they are all computing the same seat location: this STILL hasn't been fixed after years. Kitchens will fail to prioritize which canteens to send food to, ending up some being full and others empty, leading to many prisoners starving for little reason.

You focus on fixing your min-sec "freedom" need by editing the schedule for them, usually over a long period of time because that's the only way to determine the real outcome in this game. Then all of a sudden the med-secs are complaining about freedom when you've made NO CHANGES to their part of the schedule, or any physical part of their entirely separate section of the prison for that matter. There's no interaction or causation there leading to it. Makes no sense!

Certain prisoners continue to one hit your guards with the extremely deadly trait, no matter how many contingencies you have in place. Staff morale will always plumet, the only way is to continue to offer pay rises, but after a while doesn't it start to get a bit ridiculous and counterintuitive? By the way, playing with staff needs with weather and having to deal with staff upset about constant warmth is the most egregious thing ever: they are going to be outside at SOME point. Radiators only do so much as it lowers so fast and hard, having morale drop from that with little counter is annoying unless you just concede and build entirely inside.

Once staff morale drops, and it's inevitable over time, it'll continue to drop. With the fights kicking off with little to no reasoning in terms of "needs", sometimes with no solution to be had, and staff continuing to fall likes flies; the procedures you employed still just not working with no explanation.

That's the problem, constantly making amends and forsaking plans just to work around issues and bugs that really shouldn't be there. The fact the game is "finished" in their eyes is disheartening. There are a small number of user mod patches but it's still holding on by the seams. If you stick to under 200 prisoners it seems to work, for the most part, but beyond that it falls to pieces.

The game has so much charm, it's a shame.
